	<item>
		<title>Syllabus</title>
		<link>http://openlab.citytech.cuny.edu/fall11-comp1-5359/syllabus/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 22 Jun 2011 16:29:46 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>smpscanlan</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://openlab.citytech.cuny.edu/fall11-comp1-5359/?page_id=6</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h3><strong><strong>Course Title: Shared Reading, Shared Experience, Shared Lunch</strong></strong></h3>
<h5><strong><span style="text-decoration: underline">New York City College of Technology</span></strong></h5>
<h5><strong>The City University of New York</strong></h5>
<h5><strong> </strong></h5>
<h5><strong>ENG 1101, English Composition 1</strong></h5>
<h5><strong>Spring 2011</strong></h5>
<strong> </strong>

<strong>Section</strong>: 5359

<strong>Time</strong>: Tues, Thurs 11:30 – 12:45

<strong>Place</strong>:<strong> </strong>Namm 606<strong> </strong>

<strong>Instructor</strong>: Professor Sean Scanlan

<strong>Email</strong>: sscanlan@citytech.cuny.edu

<strong>Mailbox</strong>: Namm 512

<strong>Office Hours</strong>: Mon 10-11, Thurs 2:30-3:30, and by appointment

<strong>Office</strong>: Namm 520, (718) 260-5123

&nbsp;

WEEK 1: INTRODUCTION

Jan 11, M                       Discussion of course, syllabus, and text. Introductions
<div>

Jan 13, W                       About this course, Homework: WJ #1: Best/Worst reading and writing exp.

Jan 15, F                        Turn in WJ#1. Writing and Reading lecture. Homework: 132 King,

119 McDonald

&nbsp;

</div>
&nbsp;

WEEK 2: READING PRACTICE

Jan 18, M                       Martin Luther King Jr. Day—No Class
<div>

Jan 20, W                       Discuss King, McDonald, and note taking. Homework: 76 Keller and

WJ #2: response to Keller

Jan 22, F                        Turn in WJ #2 and discuss Keller. Homework: 382 Chopin and WJ #3

&nbsp;

WEEK 3: <span style="text-decoration: underline">THE NARRATIVE ESSAY (1)</span>

Jan 25, M                       Turn in WJ #3, Discuss Chopin. Lecture on summarizing

Jan 27, W                       Assign Essay #1: Narrative. In class: personal narrative. HW: read 357-60

Jan 29, F                        Discuss Narration. Homework: 361 Gates and 366 Orwell—WJ #4

&nbsp;

</div>
&nbsp;

WEEK 4: THESIS

Feb  1, M                        Turn in WJ #4. Discuss Gates and Orwell

Feb  3, W                       Quiz #1. Student example

Feb  5, F                                       First Peer Review Workshop

&nbsp;

WEEK 5: DRAFTING PROCESS

Feb  8, M                        Homework: WJ #5

Feb  10, W                     Turn in WJ #5. Second Peer Review Workshop
<div>

Feb  12, F                       <span style="text-decoration: underline">Turn in Essay #1</span>

&nbsp;

</div>
&nbsp;

&nbsp;

&nbsp;

WEEK 6: <span style="text-decoration: underline">THE PROCESS ESSAY(2)</span>

Feb  15, M                      407 Intro to Process, 411 Merrill, Homework: WJ #6
<div>

Feb  17, W                     Turn in WJ #6, 417 Sharples

Feb  19, F                       tba

&nbsp;

</div>
&nbsp;

&nbsp;

WEEK 7: GOOD SENTENCES AND GOOD PARAGRAPHS

Feb  22, M                      Examples: sentences and paragraphs
<div>

Feb  24, W                     425 Petrunkevitch

Feb  26, F                       <span style="text-decoration: underline">Turn in Essay #2</span>

&nbsp;

</div>
&nbsp;

WEEK 8: <span style="text-decoration: underline">THE PERSUASIVE ESSAY: The Music Review (3)</span>

Mar 1, M             Introduction to persuasion

Mar 3, W                        The Music Review
<div>

Mar 5, F                           Quiz #2 over “Who Should Teach Hip-Hop Studies?”

</div>
&nbsp;

WEEK 9: THE RHETORIC OF PERSUASION

Mar 8, M             Mid-term Grades Due
<div>

Mar 10, W                      Read NME music review, HW: WJ #7

Mar 12, F                        Discuss Jim Musser music reviews

&nbsp;

</div>
&nbsp;

WEEK 10:

Mar 15 – 19                    SPRING BREAK---ENJOY
<div>

&nbsp;

</div>
&nbsp;

WEEK 11: ORGANIZATION

Mar 22, M                       Second Peer Review Day for music review
<div>

Mar 24, W                      <span style="text-decoration: underline">Turn in Persuasive Essay (3)</span>

Mar 26, F                        HW: WJ #8

&nbsp;

</div>
&nbsp;

WEEK 12: <span style="text-decoration: underline">THE COMPARISON AND CONTRAST ESSAY (4)</span>
<div>

Mar 29, M                       Read 474 Comparison and Contrast introduction, 479 Twain

Mar 31, W                      Quiz #3. 489 Catton

Apr  2, F             College Holiday---No Class

&nbsp;

</div>
&nbsp;

WEEK 13: WORD CHOICES

Apr 5, M             Student examples
<div>

Apr 7, W             284 Lederer, HW: WJ #9

Apr 9, F                            290 Sedaris

&nbsp;

</div>
&nbsp;

WEEK 14: EDITING AND PROOFING

Apr 12, M                       495 Schulman

Apr 14, W                       (last day to drop a class)

Apr 16, F                        Quiz #4

&nbsp;

WEEK 15: WHAT IS GOOD WRITING?

&nbsp;
<div>

Apr 19, M                       HW: WJ #10

Apr 21, W                       First page review: matching assertions to proof

Apr 23, F                        Methodology, Question and answer

</div>
&nbsp;

WEEK 16: PEER REVIEW

Apr 26, M                       tba

Apr 28, W                       Peer Review Day

Apr 30, F                        Quiz #5

&nbsp;

WEEK 17: LAST WEEK OF CLASS

May 3, M                        tba

May 5, W                       <span style="text-decoration: underline">Essay #4 Due in Class   ----LAST DAY OF CLASS</span>

&nbsp;

End of Term: May 13]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Policies</title>
		<link>http://openlab.citytech.cuny.edu/fall11-comp1-5359/policies/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 22 Jun 2011 16:30:40 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>smpscanlan</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://openlab.citytech.cuny.edu/fall11-comp1-5359/?page_id=13</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h3><strong><strong>Course Title: Shared Reading, Shared Experience, Shared Lunch</strong></strong></h3>
<h5><strong>New York City College of Technology</strong></h5>
<h5><strong>The City University of New York</strong></h5>
<h5><strong> </strong></h5>
<h5><strong>ENG 1101, English Composition 1</strong></h5>
<h5><strong>Spring 2011</strong></h5>
<strong> </strong>

<strong>Section</strong>: 5359

<strong>Time</strong>: Tues, Thurs 11:30 – 12:45

<strong>Place</strong>:<strong> </strong>Namm 606<strong> </strong>

<strong>Instructor</strong>: Professor Sean Scanlan

<strong>Email</strong>: sscanlan@citytech.cuny.edu

<strong>Mailbox</strong>: Namm 512

<strong>Office Hours</strong>: Mon 10-11, Thurs 2:30-3:30, and by appointment

<strong>Office</strong>: Namm 520, (718) 260-5123

<strong>Description:</strong> This is a course in effective essay  writing and basic research techniques, including the use of the library.  College-level readings are assigned for classroom discussion and essay  writing.

Prerequisite: CUNY certification in reading and writing

<strong>Performance Objectives</strong>:

1. The ability to write clear and logical sentences using correct  spelling, conventional punctuation, and standard grammar and syntax.

2. The ability to paraphrase, summarize, and quote effectively.

3. The ability to develop active reading skills and to understand audience.

4. Increased skill in the critical reading of one’s own writing and that of peers and professionals.

5. Competency in various modes of writing and analyzing including:  narration and description, comparison and contrast, definition, cause  and effect, division and classification, argument and persuasion.

6. The ability to write a research paper that presents a thesis,  develops an argument, and properly incorporates and cites secondary  source material.

7. An appreciation of writing as a source of power and satisfaction  as well as the means for success in academia and career advancement.

<strong>Methods</strong>:

1. Frequent reading and writing assignment, class discussion, and group workshops

2. Use of student journals for free-writing, reading responses,  at-home reflection, and gathering material for formal and informal  writing assignments.

3. Review of grammar and punctuation rules as necessary.

<strong>Requirements</strong>:

1. Brief in-class and take-home assignments: free-writing, journal entries, summaries, and other informal assignments.

2. Five formal papers: many of your in-class and take-home assignments will be preparatory work for these essays.

3. Examinations: the mid-term and final are both in-class exams.

4. Class participation: this course is a performance, discussion, and  skills course; it is not a lecture course. Your work—writing,  discussing, listening, critiquing—will be at the center of our  activities. This work requires you to be here in body and mind. You  should come to each class prepared to speak about the assigned material.  Such preparation may require you to reflect on class questions,  concepts, and your classmates’ ideas. A good goal is to try to add to  class discussion with at least one substantial comment or question  during each class. <strong>Be proactive.</strong> If you are absent, it  is your responsibility to get notes, assignment sheets, etc. from a  classmate. When you are absent, you should email me and perhaps to set  up an office visit.<strong> </strong>

<strong>Required Texts: </strong>

<span style="text-decoration: underline">The Place Where We Dwell: Reading and Writing About New York City</span>, Juanita But and Mark Noonan, Kendall Hunt, 2007 (Second Edition).

<span style="text-decoration: underline">Note</span>: This textbook and other writing supplies are available at the City Tech bookstore located at 259 Adams Street.

<strong>Other Materials: </strong>Bring to class one sturdy notebook  with paper for notes and at least one folder with pockets for  handouts/assignments. Both spiral-bound or 3-ring are acceptable.<strong> </strong>You  must devise a system to record, store, and organize the course  materials. It is very important that you save all of your work for this  class. Devise a filing system that allows you to maintain prior drafts  and final copies of all major assignments, as well as your research  notes, outlines, and written evaluations. Save all final drafts of  assignments on a stable format such as a flash drive or on a remote hard  drive/server. Never throw away or delete drafts or notes until after  you have received your final grade. Computer/Printer malfunctions are  not viable excuses for late or lost work.<strong> </strong>

<strong>Assignments and Grading: </strong>Completing all the required  elements in good order and form constitutes the average, or a C. To  raise your grade above this average, you will need to invest your time,  talents, and energies to add insightful commentary, sound argumentative  reasoning, and show initiative in your approach to scholarship. It  should be understood that revision and refinement are necessary, though  not the sole, qualifications for success. Each major assignment will be  returned to you with specific comments and suggestions on how to improve  your work. I recommend that you make an appointment to see me if you  receive a grade of C- or lower.

There will be times when your expectations and my evaluation do not  match. I am always willing to explain my comments on your assignments,  and to discuss ways in which your work might benefit from additional  effort. Lower grades most often result from misunderstanding the  assignment goals, and from insufficiently realized or poor executions of  these goals. I do not grade beliefs or values. If you are unhappy with a  grade, or unsure as to why you received such a response to your work,  please make an appointment to see me.

The <strong>Five Essays</strong> should use correct grammar,  spelling, and punctuation. Computer spell- and grammar checkers help to  spot some errors. In general, use carefully divided and constructed  paragraphs and full sentences. The content should logically progress  from one idea to the next in such a way that the entire essay has a  clear beginning, middle, and end.

Final grades are determined by the following:
<h6>Five Essays: (60%)1. personal narrative = 5%</h6>
<h6>3. description analysis  = 15%</h6>
<h6>4. persuasive essay = 15%</h6>
<h6>5 a. research annotated bib.  = 10%</h6>
<h6>b. research essay =  10%</h6>
<h6>Journals and Quizzes = 10%</h6>
<h6>Participation and</h6>
<h6>Attendance =  10%</h6>
<h6>Mid-term Exam = 10%</h6>
<h6>Final Exam =  10%</h6>
<h6>_____________</h6>
<h6>100%</h6>
<strong>IMPORTANT NOTES:</strong>

1. <strong>Attendance</strong>: Attendance is mandatory in this  discussion-based course. Arriving late or leaving early will count as a   partial absence. City Tech’s policy states that four of more absences  will result in a WU grade. I will not grant excused absences since three  absences are permitted without penalty. Being absent is not an excuse  for missing or late work: you must get notes from a classmate and keep  up with the assignments.

2. <strong>Drafts and Typing</strong>: The five essays will require  organization, honesty, and clarity. In order to practice the process of  writing, four essays will require drafts. Essays 2-5 must be typed and  double-spaced.

3. <strong>Late Papers</strong>: One-half of a letter grade will be  deducted for late rough drafts. One full letter grade will be deducted  for late final drafts.

4. <strong>Portfolio</strong>: Each student must keep all of his/her  writing for the course. I will collect portfolios near the  end of the semester.

5.<strong> Plagiarism</strong>: Is the unauthorized use of another  person’s ideas, language, or research as your own, whether intentionally  or unintentionally. City Tech does not tolerate plagiarism. Using  proper documentation and textual analysis will help you avoid  plagiarism. If you have any questions about plagiarism, please ask me.  Any cases of plagiarism or other forms of academic dishonesty will  result in a failing grade and appropriate administrative measures.  Please familiarize yourself with City Tech’s policies on academic  honesty at:

<a href="http://www.citytech.cuny.edu/files/students/handbook.pdf">http://www.citytech.cuny.edu/files/students/handbook.pdf</a> (pp. 76-77).

<strong>New York City College of Technology Policy on Academic Integrity</strong>:

Students and all others who work with information, ideas, texts,  images, music, inventions, and other intellectual property owe their  audience and sources accuracy and honesty in using, crediting, and  citing sources. As a community of intellectual and professional workers,  the College recognizes its responsibility for providing instruction in  information literacy and academic integrity, offering models of good  practice, and responding vigilantly and appropriately to infractions of  academic integrity. Accordingly, academic dishonesty is prohibited in  The City University of New York and at New York City College of  Technology and is punishable by penalties including failing grades,  suspension, and expulsion. The complete text of the College policy on  Academic Integrity may be found in the catalog.

6.<strong> Be on time:</strong> tardiness disrupts the entire class. <strong>Come prepared:</strong> turn off/silence all gadgets, please.

7. <strong>The Atrium Learning Center</strong>: For each of the five  essays, you should take advantage of the writing tutors at the Learning  Center. This is an excellent recourse for writers of all abilities.  ATRIUM LEARNING CENTER: Atrium Building G-18, Director: Judith Rockway,  Phone: 718-260-5874.<a href="mailto:jrockway@citytech.cuny.edu">jrockway@citytech.cuny.edu</a>.

&nbsp;

&nbsp;]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>LEARNING COMMUNITY COURSES</title>
		<link>http://openlab.citytech.cuny.edu/fall11-comp1-5359/2011/08/15/40/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 15 Aug 2011 16:32:08 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>smpscanlan</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://openlab.citytech.cuny.edu/fall11-comp1-5359/?p=40</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[ ]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>40</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2011-08-15 12:32:08</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2011-08-15 16:32:08</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>

		<category domain="nav_menu" nicename="course-menu"><![CDATA[course menu]]></category>
		<wp:postmeta>

	<item>
		<title>Course Policies</title>
		<link>http://openlab.citytech.cuny.edu/fall11-comp1-5359/2011/08/15/41/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 15 Aug 2011 16:32:08 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>smpscanlan</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://openlab.citytech.cuny.edu/fall11-comp1-5359/?p=41</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Course Title: Shared Reading, Shared Experience, Shared Lunch
New York City College of Technology
The City University of New York
 
ENG 1101, English Composition 1
Spring 2011
 

Section: 5359

Time: Tues, Thurs 11:30 – 12:45

Place: Namm 606 

Instructor: Professor Sean Scanlan

Email: sscanlan@citytech.cuny.edu

Mailbox: Namm 512

Office Hours: Mon 10-11, Thurs 2:30-3:30, and by appointment

Office: Namm 520, (718) 260-5123

Description: This is a course in effective essay  writing and basic research techniques, including the use of the library.  College-level readings are assigned for classroom discussion and essay  writing.

Prerequisite: CUNY certification in reading and writing

Performance Objectives:

1. The ability to write clear and logical sentences using correct  spelling, conventional punctuation, and standard grammar and syntax.

2. The ability to paraphrase, summarize, and quote effectively.

3. The ability to develop active reading skills and to understand audience.

4. Increased skill in the critical reading of one’s own writing and that of peers and professionals.

5. Competency in various modes of writing and analyzing including:  narration and description, comparison and contrast, definition, cause  and effect, division and classification, argument and persuasion.

6. The ability to write a research paper that presents a thesis,  develops an argument, and properly incorporates and cites secondary  source material.

7. An appreciation of writing as a source of power and satisfaction  as well as the means for success in academia and career advancement.

Methods:

1. Frequent reading and writing assignment, class discussion, and group workshops

2. Use of student journals for free-writing, reading responses,  at-home reflection, and gathering material for formal and informal  writing assignments.

3. Review of grammar and punctuation rules as necessary.

Requirements:

1. Brief in-class and take-home assignments: free-writing, journal entries, summaries, and other informal assignments.

2. Five formal papers: many of your in-class and take-home assignments will be preparatory work for these essays.

3. Examinations: the mid-term and final are both in-class exams.

4. Class participation: this course is a performance, discussion, and  skills course; it is not a lecture course. Your work—writing,  discussing, listening, critiquing—will be at the center of our  activities. This work requires you to be here in body and mind. You  should come to each class prepared to speak about the assigned material.  Such preparation may require you to reflect on class questions,  concepts, and your classmates’ ideas. A good goal is to try to add to  class discussion with at least one substantial comment or question  during each class. Be proactive. If you are absent, it  is your responsibility to get notes, assignment sheets, etc. from a  classmate. When you are absent, you should email me and perhaps to set  up an office visit. 

Required Texts: 

1. Alfred Rosa and Paul Eschholz. Models for Writers. Boston: Bedford/St. Martin’s, 2010.

2. M. Jerry Weiss and Helen Weiss. The Signet Book of American Essays. New York: Signet Classic, 2006.

Note: Both of these texts are available at the City Tech bookstore located at 259 Adams Street.

Other Materials: Bring to class one sturdy notebook  with paper for notes and at least one folder with pockets for  handouts/assignments. Both spiral-bound or 3-ring are acceptable. You  must devise a system to record, store, and organize the course  materials. It is very important that you save all of your work for this  class. Devise a filing system that allows you to maintain prior drafts  and final copies of all major assignments, as well as your research  notes, outlines, and written evaluations. Save all final drafts of  assignments on a stable format such as a flash drive or on a remote hard  drive/server. Never throw away or delete drafts or notes until after  you have received your final grade. Computer/Printer malfunctions are  not viable excuses for late or lost work. 

Assignments and Grading: Completing all the required  elements in good order and form constitutes the average, or a C. To  raise your grade above this average, you will need to invest your time,  talents, and energies to add insightful commentary, sound argumentative  reasoning, and show initiative in your approach to scholarship. It  should be understood that revision and refinement are necessary, though  not the sole, qualifications for success. Each major assignment will be  returned to you with specific comments and suggestions on how to improve  your work. I recommend that you make an appointment to see me if you  receive a grade of C- or lower.

There will be times when your expectations and my evaluation do not  match. I am always willing to explain my comments on your assignments,  and to discuss ways in which your work might benefit from additional  effort. Lower grades most often result from misunderstanding the  assignment goals, and from insufficiently realized or poor executions of  these goals. I do not grade beliefs or values. If you are unhappy with a  grade, or unsure as to why you received such a response to your work,  please make an appointment to see me.

The Five Essays should use correct grammar,  spelling, and punctuation. Computer spell- and grammar checkers help to  spot some errors. In general, use carefully divided and constructed  paragraphs and full sentences. The content should logically progress  from one idea to the next in such a way that the entire essay has a  clear beginning, middle, and end.

Final grades are determined by the following:
Five Essays: (60%)1. personal narrative               5%
2. revised personal narr.         5%
3. description analysis          15%
4. persuasive essay              15%
5 a. research annotated bib.  10%
b. research essay               10%
Journals and Quizzes              10%
Participation and
Attendance                                    10%
Mid-term Exam                       10%
Final Exam                             10%
_____________
100%
IMPORTANT NOTES:

1. Attendance: Attendance is mandatory in this  discussion-based course. Arriving late or leaving early will count as a   partial absence. City Tech’s policy states that four of more absences  will result in a WU grade. I will not grant excused absences since three  absences are permitted without penalty. Being absent is not an excuse  for missing or late work: you must get notes from a classmate and keep  up with the assignments.

2. Drafts and Typing: The five essays will require  organization, honesty, and clarity. In order to practice the process of  writing, four essays will require drafts. Essays 2-5 must be typed and  double-spaced.

3. Late Papers: One-half of a letter grade will be  deducted for late rough drafts. One full letter grade will be deducted  for late final drafts.

4. Portfolio: Each student must keep all of his/her  writing for the course. I will collect these portfolios once near the  end of the semester.

5. Plagiarism: Is the unauthorized use of another  person’s ideas, language, or research as your own, whether intentionally  or unintentionally. City Tech does not tolerate plagiarism. Using  proper documentation and textual analysis will help you avoid  plagiarism. If you have any questions about plagiarism, please ask me.  Any cases of plagiarism or other forms of academic dishonesty will  result in a failing grade and appropriate administrative measures.  Please familiarize yourself with City Tech’s policies on academic  honesty at:

http://www.citytech.cuny.edu/files/students/handbook.pdf (pp. 76-77).

New York City College of Technology Policy on Academic Integrity:

Students and all others who work with information, ideas, texts,  images, music, inventions, and other intellectual property owe their  audience and sources accuracy and honesty in using, crediting, and  citing sources. As a community of intellectual and professional workers,  the College recognizes its responsibility for providing instruction in  information literacy and academic integrity, offering models of good  practice, and responding vigilantly and appropriately to infractions of  academic integrity. Accordingly, academic dishonesty is prohibited in  The City University of New York and at New York City College of  Technology and is punishable by penalties including failing grades,  suspension, and expulsion. The complete text of the College policy on  Academic Integrity may be found in the catalog.

6. Be on time: tardiness disrupts the entire class. Come prepared: turn off/silence all gadgets, please.

7. The Atrium Learning Center: For each of the five  essays, you should take advantage of the writing tutors at the Learning  Center. This is an excellent recourse for writers of all abilities.  ATRIUM LEARNING CENTER: Atrium Building G-18, Director: Judith Rockway,  Phone: 718-260-5874.jrockway@citytech.cuny.edu.

 

 ]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>SYLLABUS</title>
		<link>http://openlab.citytech.cuny.edu/fall11-comp1-5359/2011/08/15/44/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 15 Aug 2011 16:32:08 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>smpscanlan</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://openlab.citytech.cuny.edu/fall11-comp1-5359/?p=44</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Course Title: Shared Reading, Shared Experience, Shared Lunch
New York City College of Technology
The City University of New York
 
ENG 1101, English Composition 1
Spring 2011
 

Section: 5359

Time: Tues, Thurs 11:30 – 12:45

Place: Namm 606 

Instructor: Professor Sean Scanlan

Email: sscanlan@citytech.cuny.edu

Mailbox: Namm 512

Office Hours: Mon 10-11, Thurs 2:30-3:30, and by appointment

Office: Namm 520, (718) 260-5123

 

WEEK 1: INTRODUCTION

Jan 11, M                       Discussion of course, syllabus, and text. Introductions


Jan 13, W                       About this course, Homework: WJ #1: Best/Worst reading and writing exp.

Jan 15, F                        Turn in WJ#1. Writing and Reading lecture. Homework: 132 King,

119 McDonald

 


 

WEEK 2: READING PRACTICE

Jan 18, M                       Martin Luther King Jr. Day—No Class


Jan 20, W                       Discuss King, McDonald, and note taking. Homework: 76 Keller and

WJ #2: response to Keller

Jan 22, F                        Turn in WJ #2 and discuss Keller. Homework: 382 Chopin and WJ #3

 

WEEK 3: THE NARRATIVE ESSAY (1)

Jan 25, M                       Turn in WJ #3, Discuss Chopin. Lecture on summarizing

Jan 27, W                       Assign Essay #1: Narrative. In class: personal narrative. HW: read 357-60

Jan 29, F                        Discuss Narration. Homework: 361 Gates and 366 Orwell—WJ #4

 


 

WEEK 4: THESIS

Feb  1, M                        Turn in WJ #4. Discuss Gates and Orwell

Feb  3, W                       Quiz #1. Student example

Feb  5, F                                       First Peer Review Workshop

 

WEEK 5: DRAFTING PROCESS

Feb  8, M                        Homework: WJ #5

Feb  10, W                     Turn in WJ #5. Second Peer Review Workshop


Feb  12, F                       Turn in Essay #1

 


 

 

 

WEEK 6: THE PROCESS ESSAY(2)

Feb  15, M                      407 Intro to Process, 411 Merrill, Homework: WJ #6


Feb  17, W                     Turn in WJ #6, 417 Sharples

Feb  19, F                       tba

 


 

 

WEEK 7: GOOD SENTENCES AND GOOD PARAGRAPHS

Feb  22, M                      Examples: sentences and paragraphs


Feb  24, W                     425 Petrunkevitch

Feb  26, F                       Turn in Essay #2

 


 

WEEK 8: THE PERSUASIVE ESSAY: The Music Review (3)

Mar 1, M             Introduction to persuasion

Mar 3, W                        The Music Review


Mar 5, F                           Quiz #2 over “Who Should Teach Hip-Hop Studies?”


 

WEEK 9: THE RHETORIC OF PERSUASION

Mar 8, M             Mid-term Grades Due


Mar 10, W                      Read NME music review, HW: WJ #7

Mar 12, F                        Discuss Jim Musser music reviews

 


 

WEEK 10:

Mar 15 – 19                    SPRING BREAK—ENJOY


 


 

WEEK 11: ORGANIZATION

Mar 22, M                       Second Peer Review Day for music review


Mar 24, W                      Turn in Persuasive Essay (3)

Mar 26, F                        HW: WJ #8

 


 

WEEK 12: THE COMPARISON AND CONTRAST ESSAY (4)


Mar 29, M                       Read 474 Comparison and Contrast introduction, 479 Twain

Mar 31, W                      Quiz #3. 489 Catton

Apr  2, F             College Holiday—No Class

 


 

WEEK 13: WORD CHOICES

Apr 5, M             Student examples


Apr 7, W             284 Lederer, HW: WJ #9

Apr 9, F                            290 Sedaris

 


 

WEEK 14: EDITING AND PROOFING

Apr 12, M                       495 Schulman

Apr 14, W                       (last day to drop a class)

Apr 16, F                        Quiz #4

 

WEEK 15: WHAT IS GOOD WRITING?

 


Apr 19, M                       HW: WJ #10

Apr 21, W                       First page review: matching assertions to proof

Apr 23, F                        Methodology, Question and answer


 

WEEK 16: PEER REVIEW

Apr 26, M                       tba

Apr 28, W                       Peer Review Day

Apr 30, F                        Quiz #5

 

WEEK 17: LAST WEEK OF CLASS

May 3, M                        tba

May 5, W                       Essay #4 Due in Class   —-LAST DAY OF CLASS

 

End of Term: May 13]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>BrooklynBridge</title>
		<link>http://openlab.citytech.cuny.edu/fall11-comp1-5359/?attachment_id=70</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 15 Aug 2011 17:40:06 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>smpscanlan</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://openlab.citytech.cuny.edu/fall11-comp1-5359/files/2011/08/BrooklynBridge.jpeg</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>70</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2011-08-15 13:40:06</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2011-08-15 17:40:06</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>

		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Hi Class,

&nbsp;

Today we are walking from City Tech to Pier 6, where we will investigate the park system that--eventually--will run from Atlantic Avenue all the way to the Brooklyn Bridge.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Exams: Midterm and Final</title>
		<link>http://openlab.citytech.cuny.edu/fall11-comp1-5359/exams-midterm-and-final/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 15 Aug 2011 17:33:55 +0000</pubDate>

&nbsp;

Notice that the site is now up and running.

Please post often.

Don't forget to read over your writing cuz the whole world might read it.

&nbsp;

Cheers,

Sean]]></content:encoded>
